title: Recursive closures' error is confusing

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
### Code

```Rust
let some_recursive_closure = |x: u8| {
    println!("{}", x);
    if x != 0 {
        some_recursive_closure(x-1);
    }
};
```


### Current output

```Shell
error[E0425]: cannot find function `some_recursive_closure` in this scope
 --> src/main.rs:4:9
  |
4 |         some_recursive_closure(x-1);
  |         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ not found in this scope

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0425`.
```


### Desired output

```Shell
error[E####]: attempted recursion inside a closure
 --> src/main.rs:4:9
  |
4 |         some_recursive_closure(x-1);
  |         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ closures are not permitted to recurse

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E####`.
```


### Rationale and extra context

I find this error message very confusing, because, well, `some_recursive_closure` _does_ exist in this scope! I just defined it!

The _actual_ problem is that there is an attempt at closure recursion here, which is apparently not permitted. I am not informed enough to judge whether it should, but at the absolute least the error ought to be a smidge more understandable.

